questions.text:
Which of the following are storage symptoms of BPH?
  1. Urgency
  2. Enuresis
  3. Hesitancy
  4. Frequency
  5. Dribbling
questions.solution:
Urgency, enuresis and frequency are storage symptoms.

Lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) can be classified as:

Storage Voiding
  • Frequency (earliest symptom in BPH)
  • Nocturia
  • Urgency
  • Urge incontinence
  • Nocturnal incontinence (enuresis)
  • Hesitancy
  • Poor flow
  • Intermittent stream
  • Dribbling
  • Sensation of poor bladder emptying
  • Episodes of near retention

Storage symptoms are seen in conditions where the bladder is irritated. Voiding symptoms are common in conditions causing bladder outlet obstruction. In benign prostatic hyperplasia, both storage and voiding symptoms are present.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with fever, chills, and dysuria. On per-rectal examination, his prostate was tender and boggy. His PSA level was 7.4 ng/dl. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute bacterial prostatitis and should be managed by antibiotics.

A rigorous and prolonged treatment for 2-6 weeks with an antibiotic that penetrates the prostate wall is indicated (trimethoprim, ciprofloxacin or aminoglycoside). Incomplete infection eradication lead to recurrent attacks and chronic prostatitis.

Acute bacterial prostatitis is usually caused by an ascending urinary tract infection (UTI) or reflux of infected urine into prostatic ducts. The most common organism is Escherichia coli. An associated increase in levels of PSA(>4ng/ml) may be present due to prostate inflammation.

Catheterization and prostatic massage are contraindicated in patients with suspected acute prostatitis, as they increase the chance for bacteremia and sepsis. Instead, suprapubic tap should be performed to alleviate retention.

Chronic bacterial prostatitis is the sequela of inadequately treated acute prostatitis.
Diagnosis includes: 

  • Three-glass urine test - If the first glass with the initial urine sample is clear, but the second and third samples contain prostatic threads and leukocytes, it indicates the presence of prostatitis.
  • Digital rectal examination - Prostate may be normal, boggy, or tender.
  • Prostatic fluid examination - post-prostatic massage fluid shows pus cells and bacteria.

questions.text: Which is the most common organism causing acute bacterial prostatitis?
questions.solution:
The most common organism causing acute bacterial prostatitis (ABP) is Escherichia coli.

It is commonly caused by an ascending urethral infection or reflux of infected urine into prostatic ducts. Sexually transmissible infections and other urinary pathogens, such as Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus faecalis may also be responsible.

The patient presents with fever, perineal pain, chills and rigor, and dysuria. Per rectal examination will reveal a tender, boggy prostate. Care should be taken to avoid aggressive palpation or prostatic massage as it can lead to bacterial dissemination and sepsis.

Urine examination and culture should be done. Urine examination reveals threads in urine.

Management:  

Patients with systemic signs of infection should be admitted for IV antibiotics, hydration, and monitoring of laboratory parameters.

Patients who have no signs of systemic infection, who can tolerate oral intake, and who have no urinary retention can be treated with oral antibiotics. Antibiotics are given for 2-6 weeks to ensure the eradication of the infection as antibiotics don't penetrate the prostate capsule easily. 

For outpatient therapy: Ciprofloxacin 500 mg oral every 12 hours or levofloxacin 500 mg OD or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole double-strength tablet oral every 12 hours can be used.

For hospitalized patients: Intravenous ciprofloxacin or levofloxacin with or without an aminoglycoside (gentamicin or tobramycin) or intravenous beta-lactam with or without an aminoglycoside. Gram-positive infections are treated with cephalosporins (cephalexin, cefazolin) or dicloxacillin and vancomycin.

questions.text: Which of following compounds form endogenous prostatic calculi?
questions.solution:
Endogenous calculi are most commonly composed of calcium phosphate.

Exogenous calculi are urinary calculi that are arrested in the prostatic urethra. They are relatively rare.

Corpora amylacea are benign histological findings in prostate glands. Prostatic calculi are thought to develop from the calcification of corpora amylacea.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the medical management of benign prostatic hyperplasia?

choices.text: 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors take at least 6 months to act.
5-alpha-reductase inhibitors act best when the gland is small.

questions.solution:
5-alpha-reductase inhibitors act best when the prostate is large(>50g).

The pathogenesis of BPH has a static and dynamic component responsible for the lower urinary tract symptoms. Conversion of testosterone to DHT is responsible for prostatic stromal hypertrophy which is the static component of BPH. The contraction of smooth muscles in the prostate is considered the dynamic component of BPH. 

  Alpha-blockers  5-alpha-reductase inhibitors
Mechanism of action Inhibit the contraction of smooth muscles in the prostate. Inhibit the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) 
Onset of action Work quickly To be taken for at least 6 months
Example Tamsulosin Finasteride
Adverse effects

Dizziness (due to postural hypotension)

Abnormal ejaculation

Dizziness

Impotence

questions.text: Which of the following findings is not an indication to perform prostatectomy in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia?
questions.solution:
Increased frequency alone is not an indication for prostatectomy.

Increasing difficulty in micturition, with considerable frequency during both day and night, delay in starting, and a poor stream are the usual symptoms for which surgery is advised.

Other indications include the following:

  • Acute retention
  • Chronic retention and renal impairment
    • Residual urine of ≥200 mL 
    • Raised blood urea
    • Hydroureter or hydronephrosis
  • Complications of bladder outflow obstruction
    • Stone
    • Infection
    • Diverticuli
  • Hemorrhage - Venous bleeding from a ruptured vein overlying the prostate

questions.text: Identify the approach for surgery of the prostate as shown in the image:
questions.solution:
The image shows the transvesical approach, also known as Freyer approach.

In this approach, the bladder is opened and the prostate is enucleated by putting a finger into the urethra, pushing forward towards the pubes to separate the lateral lobes, and then working the finger between the adenoma and the false capsule.

Among the other approaches, TURP is most commonly performed.

questions.text: As a first-year surgery resident, you have scrubbed in to assist a urologist on a TURP procedure. Up to what distal anatomical landmark do you expect him to resect?
questions.solution:
Verumontanum is used as the distal-most border of the resection in transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP). This prevents damage to the external urethral sphincter which is located just distal to the verumontanum.

Damage to the external urethral sphincter leads to urinary incontinence.

The bladder neck is the proximal limit of resection.

questions.text: A patient in your ward is scheduled for monopolar-TURP. Which of the given fluids should be used for irrigation during the procedure?
questions.solution:
The best irrigating fluid for M-TURP is 1.5% isotonic glycine.

M-TURP removes tissue with a wire loop that has an electrical current flowing in one direction (monopolar). The surgical site is irrigated with a non-conducting non-ionic fluid as the use of an ionic solution leads to dissipation of the cutting current and poor cutting efficacy. Thus, normal saline and N/5 saline cannot be used.

The use of distilled water in TURP leads to the water-intoxication syndrome. 

Bipolar transurethral resection of the prostate (B-TURP) uses a specialized resecting loop that incorporates both the active and the return portions of the circuit on the same electrode and an ionic irrigating solution such as normal saline can be used safely.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with benign prostatic hypertrophy underwent TURP.  An hour later, he was found to have an altered sensorium and had several bouts of vomiting. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The most probable cause for the above-mentioned symptoms is water intoxication also known as transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) syndrome. 

Absorption of water into the circulation at the time of transurethral urethral resection can lead to :

  • Hyponatremia, which may manifest as confusion, nausea, and vomiting
  • Congestive cardiac failure
  • Hemolysis 

It is managed by fluid restriction.

The use of isotonic glycine for irrigation during resection reduces the incidence of water intoxication.

questions.text: A man presents with a history of minimal ejaculation at sexual climax and passing cloudy urine after. He is a known diabetic and underwent TURP 6 months ago. What is the mechanism leading to this complication?

choices.text: Injury to the external urethral sphincter
Disruption of the autonomic nerve supply to the corpora of the penis
Over use of coagulating diathermy during the procedure

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario above suggests the patient has retrograde ejaculation. The most likely mechanism of its development is disruption of the bladder neck. 

Retrograde ejaculation is the most common complication of transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP). 

Option A: Injury to the external urethral sphincter causes incontinence following TURP. 

Option B: Disruption of the autonomic nerve supply to the corpora of the penis causes impotence. 

Option C: Overuse of coagulating diathermy following TURP causes bladder neck contracture. 

Other complications of TURP include:

  • Transurethral resection of prostate (TUR) syndrome 
  • Primary and secondary hemorrhage
  • Perforation of the bladder or the prostatic capsule 
  • Sepsis 
  • Urethral stricture
Note:Transurethral microwave thermotherapy (TUMT), Transurethral needle ablation (TUNA), and laser vaporization are less invasive methods used for the treatment of BPH. They have a decreased incidence of ejaculatory dysfunction and hemorrhage.

questions.text: On per rectal examination, which of the following findings will help you identify a malignant prostate lesion?

choices.text: Rectal mucosa mobile over the prostate

questions.solution:
Palpable nodules over the prostate is highly suggestive of carcinoma.

Features of carcinoma of the prostate Features of benign disease of the prostate
  • Hard consistency
  • Rectal mucosa immobile over the prostate
  • Obliteration of the median groove
  • Nodular surface
  • Firm consistency
  • Rectal mucosa mobile over the prostate
  • Residual urine may be felt as a fluctuating swelling above the prostate
  • Smooth surface

questions.text: A 68- year-old patient presents with difficulty in initiating micturition. A DRE reveals an enlarged nodular prostate with adherent rectal mucosa. PSA was found to be 25 ng/ml and a biopsy result was suggestive of adenocarcinoma. Which of the following statements is false regarding his condition ?

choices.text: PSA is a not specific marker for the condition.
Gleason score correlates with the pathological stage
It is associated with decreased % free PSA
It arises from the transitional zone of the gland.

questions.solution:
Prostatic carcinoma, as indicated in the clinical scenario, arises from the peripheral zone of the gland.

Anatomically, the prostate is divided into three zones. 

  • The peripheral zone lies posteriorly and has an abundance of prostatic glands. 
  • The central zone lies posterior to the urethral lumen and above the seminal vesicles as they course through the prostate. 
  • The transitional zone is periurethral.

Benign prostatic hyperplasia arises from the transitional zone.

Gleason grading may be used after biopsy to evaluate the stage of histopathological specimen. Gleason scores range from 6 to 10 where 6 is low risk for prostate cancer while 10 is high risk.

PSA (prostatic specific antigen) is a glycoprotein peptidase that facilitates the liquefaction of semen. It is useful for screening and for monitoring response to therapy but is neither specific nor sensitive to the condition as it can be elevated due to old age and benign conditions such as prostatitis and BPH.

Slightly elevated total PSA (between 4.0 and 10.0 ng/mL) and low free PSA (<25%) is suspicious for prostate cancer.

questions.text: A 63-year-old patient comes to the urology OPD with hesitancy, incomplete voiding, and pelvic pain. On a digital rectal examination, an irregularly enlarged prostate with a nodular surface is felt. The rectal mucosa does not move freely over it. A biopsy using an automated gun is planned. How many biopsy cores should be obtained?
questions.solution:
Ideally, 12 systematic biopsy cores are obtained in patients with suspected prostatic cancer.

A 12-core systematic biopsy that incorporates apical and far-lateral cores in template distribution allows maximum cancer detection. It also avoids detection of insignificant prostate cancers and the need of a repeat biopsy.

Multi-parametric MRI (mpMRI) is a valuable tool in the diagnostic and management pathway in men at risk of prostate cancer.

questions.text: A 77-year-old man was evaluated for a nodule found on his prostate. His PSA levels were 15 ng/dl and a transrectal biopsy indicated a malignancy. Which of the following statements is false regarding its spread?

choices.text: Local spread can occur to the seminal vesicles.
Direct involvement of rectum is common.
Obturator nodes are most commonly involved.
Spread by bloodstream usually occurs to the bones.

questions.solution:
Palpable nodules over the prostate with raised PSA are highly suggestive of carcinoma. direct involvement of the rectum is rare but it may become stenosed by the tumor infiltrating around it.

Option A: Local invasion occurs upwards, first involving seminal vesicles, bladder neck, and trigone; this is followed by distal invasion to the external sphincter. Obstruction of one or both ureters can occur resulting in anuria. 

Option C: Lymph nodes involved are obturator lymph nodes, external iliac nodes, and occasionally retroperitoneal, mediastinal, and supraclavicular lymph nodes. 

Option D: Spread by the bloodstream occurs mostly to the bones; the bones involved most frequently in carcinoma of the prostate are the pelvic bones and the lower lumbar vertebrae.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents with an enlarged, hard, nodular prostate. Further investigations reveal a tumor that has extended through the prostatic capsule to the seminal vesicle. Other adjacent structures are not involved. What is the stage of his disease?
questions.solution:
The stage of the tumor that has extended through the prostatic capsule to the seminal vesicle and not to other adjacent structures is T3b.

Staging of prostate carcinoma:
Tx Primary tumor cannot be assessed
T0 No evidence of primary tumor
T1 Clinically inapparent tumor. Neither palpable nor visible on imaging
T1a Incidental histologic finding in 5% or less of tissue resected
T1b Incidental histologic findings in more than 5% of tissue resected
T1c Tumor identified by needle biopsy (for example, because of elevated PSA level)
T2

Tumor confined within the prostate
T2a

Tumor involves one-half of one lobe or less
T2b

Tumor involves more than one-half of one lobe but not both lobes
T2c

Tumor involves both lobes
T3

Tumors extend through the prostate capsule
T3a Extracapsular extension (unilateral or bilateral)
T3b

Tumor invades seminal vesicle(s)
T4 Tumor is fixed or invades adjacent structures other than seminal vesicles, such as external sphincter, rectum, bladder, levator muscles, and/or pelvic wall

questions.text: A 75-year-old man provisionally diagnosed with BPH underwent a TURP procedure. Histopathological exam of the resected tissue revealed a tumor involving less than 5% of the specimen. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
A tumor discovered incidentally on TURP present in <5% of resected tissue is staged as T1a. For older men, conservative treatment is done for stage T1a prostatic carcinoma.

Radical surgical treatment might be considered in younger (<70 years) men with the same stage of the disease.

Staging of prostate carcinoma:
Tx Primary tumor cannot be assessed
T0 No evidence of primary tumor
T1 Clinically inapparent tumor. Neither palpable nor visible on imaging
T1a Incidental histologic finding in 5% or less of tissue resected
T1b Incidental histologic findings in more than 5% of tissue resected
T1c Tumor identified by needle biopsy (for example, because of elevated PSA)
T2

Tumor confined within the prostate
T2a

Tumor involves one-half of one lobe or less
T2b

Tumor involves more than one-half of one lobe but not both lobes
T2c

Tumor involves both lobes
T3

Tumors extend through the prostate capsule
T3a Extracapsular extension (unilateral or bilateral)
T3b

Tumor invades seminal vesicle(s)
T4 Tumor is fixed or invades adjacent structures other than seminal vesicles, such as external sphincter, rectum, bladder, levator muscles, and/or pelvic wall
Management of Prostatic Carcinoma 
Stage of cancer Age > 70 or Gleason score=6 Age < 70 or Gleason score >6  
Early prostate cancer: T1B,T2A Active surveillance Radical prostatectomy    
Locally advanced prostate cancer: T2B, T2C, T3, T4, N1 Brachytherapy + Androgen deprivation therapy Brachytherapy + Radical prostatectomy   
Metastatic prostate cancer Androgen deprivation therapy Chemotherapy and radiotherapy (hormone-resistant  tumor)Radiopharmaceutical therapy (hormone resistant bony metastasis)

questions.text: Orchidectomy is used as treatment for which of the following stages of prostate cancer?
questions.solution:
Orchidectomy is performed to carry out androgen ablation in the treatment of locally advanced disease in the elderly. It is also done to manage metastatic disease.

Bilateral orchidectomy, whether total or subcapsular, will eliminate the major source of testosterone production. LHRH analogs such as goserelin and buserelin along with anti-androgens such as flutamide is used to perform medical androgen ablation.

Management of Prostatic Carcinoma
Stage of cancer Age > 70 or Gleason score=6  Age < 70 or Gleason score >6  
Early prostate cancer: T1,T2A Active surveillance Radical prostatectomy  
Locally advanced prostate cancer: T2B, T2C, T3, T4, N1 Brachytherapy + Androgen deprivation therapy Brachytherapy + Radical prostatectomy   
Metastatic prostate cancer Androgen deprivation therapy 
Chemotherapy and radiotherapy (hormone-resistant  tumor)
Radiopharmaceutical therapy (hormone resistant bony metastasis)

questions.text: A 77-year-old man presented with worsening hip and back pain. The X-ray revealed the given lesions  The patient had undergone an orchidectomy three years ago to manage his prostatic carcinoma. However, recent serial estimations of PSA have shown an increasing trend. What is the treatment of choice for his condition?
questions.solution:
Blastic lesions on X-Ray after surgical castration (therapeutic orchidectomy) in patients with prostatic carcinoma is suggestive of hormone-resistant bone metastasis. The treatment of choice for hormone-resistant bone metastasis is radiopharmaceutical therapy with radium-223.

Radium-223 is a radioactive isotope that emits low levels of alpha-particle radiation. The alpha-particle radiation causes double-strand breaks in DNA, which kills cells. Radium-223 is a “calcium mimetic” that accumulates preferentially in areas of bone undergoing increased turnover, such as areas of bone metastases.

Management of Prostatic Carcinoma 
Stage of cancer Age>70 or Gleason score=6  Age<70 or Gleason score>6    
Early prostate cancer: T1, T2A Active surveillance Radical prostatectomy   
Locally advanced prostate cancer: T2B, T2C, T3, T4, N1 Brachytherapy + Androgen deprivation therapy Brachytherapy + Radical prostatectomy
Metastatic prostate cancer

Androgen deprivation therapy

Chemotherapy and radiotherapy (hormone-resistant  tumor)

Radiopharmaceutical therapy (hormone-resistant bony metastasis) 

Related Pearl: Types of metastasis(osteoblastic or osteolytic) and their primary:

Predominantly osteoblastic:

  • Prostate cancer
  • Osteosarcoma 
  • Medullary carcinoma thyroid

Mixed osteoblastic and osteolytic:

  • Breast cancer(preponderance toward osteolytic)
  • Lymphoma
  • Urothelial carcinoma 
  • Lung cancer

Predominantly osteolytic:

  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Multiple myeloma 
  • Thyroid carcinoma(except medullary carcinoma thyroid)
  • Gastrointestinal tract carcinoma
  • Malignant melanoma

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is used in the treatment of prostate cancer?
questions.solution:
Sipuleucel-T (Provenge) is an autologous prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP)-loaded dendritic cell vaccine. 

It is approved for patients with hormone-resistant, metastatic prostate cancer with minimal or no cancer-related symptoms.

Other immunotherapies in prostate cancer include:

  • GVAX allogeneic recombinant whole-cell vaccine
  • Immune checkpoint inhibitors such as PD-1/PD-L1 inhibitor
  • CTLA-4 inhibitor

Option A: Talimogene laherparepvec (T-VEC) has demonstrated therapeutic activity in melanoma.

Option B: Bacillus Calmette–Guérin is used for bladder carcinoma.

Option D: Algenpantucel-L is used as immunotherapy in pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is used in laser enucleation of the prostate?
questions.solution:
Ho-YAG laser is the most common laser used in enucleation of the prostate. The procedure is known as Holmium laser enucleation of the prostate (HoLEP).

Laser reduce the duration of the procedure and the risk of harmorrhage.

KTPA green light laser is the best laser that can be used. It causes vaporisation of prostatic tissue. As it is hemostatic in nature, it can be safely used in patients on anticoagulants.

Related Pearl: Lasers used in various specialities

Laser Major indications
Nd:YAG

Ophthalmology

  • Posterior capsulotomy
  • Iridotomy
  • Vitreolysis

Urology

  • Bladder cancer

GIT

  • Fragmentation of gall stones
Holmium YAG

Urology

  • Lithotripsy
  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia
  • Urethral stricture

 
Carbon dioxide 

ENT

  • Stapedectomy
  • Tympanomastoid surgery
Excimer (argon fluoride)

Ophthalmology

  • LASIK
Argon green

Ophthalmology

  • Retinal photocoagulation

ENT

  • Middle ear surgery
Pulsed dye laser (PDL)

Dermatology

  • Port-wine stain
  • Strawberry birthmarks
